contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: amount to vapor ... chasing the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: vapor ... an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: vapor ... an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how strenuously the person works. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: works so hard and tries in his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: vapor ... an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For everything there is an appointed time, and a season for every purpose

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how common wicked behavior is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I have seen the wickedness ... wickedness was there

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "living" is a nominal adjective that refers to people who are living. The phrase "those who are still alive" means the same thing as "the living." Alternate translation: "the people who are still alive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.glQuote: the living, who are still alive

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: vapor ... an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "alive" and "walking around" mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize living people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: vapor ... an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that you should think first before you speak to God about a matter. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not be too quick ... do not let your heart be too quick

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. Alternate translation: "lives many years" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: lives many years, so that the days of his years are many

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors that emphasize the idea of things being useless and futile. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: vapor ... an attempt to shepherd the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: self-righteous, wise in your own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize people respecting God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: who respect God ... who stand before him and show him respect

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings and emphasize the importance of enjoying the basic activities of life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: eat your bread with joy, and drink your wine with a happy heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. This speaks of people finding out what you have said as if a small bird would hear what you say and tell other people. Alternate translation: "For a bird may hear what you say and tell the matter to other people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For a bird of the sky ... can spread the matter

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined to emphasize that the man should be happy while he is young. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Take joy, young man, in your youth, and let your heart be joyful in the days of your youth
